item.title: My Guardian Alien
item.description:
My Guardian Alien ðŸ”—

A 2024 Philippine television drama series broadcast by GMA Network. It is a science fiction drama directed by Zig Madamba Dulay, starring Marian Rivera. The series premiered on April 1, 2024, and concluded on June 28, 2024, with 65 episodes. Originally titled Against All Odds, it was later renamed. The series is also available for streaming on YouTube.

Premise ðŸ”—

The plot centers around Katherine, who dies in a shooting accident. During her funeral, an alien “pod” lands on Earth, and the alien takes Katherine’s form.

Cast and Characters ðŸ”—

This section lists the actors and the characters they portray in the series.

Lead Cast:

  • Marian Rivera plays Katherine Villegas-Soriano / 11-1-20-8-5-22-9-12-5 / Grace B. Formin / Mommy Two.

Supporting Cast:

  • Gabby Concepcion plays Carlos Soriano.
  • Max Collins plays Venus del Rosario.
  • Raphael Landicho plays Adrian “Doy” Soriano.
  • Gabby Eigenmann plays Cepheus “Ceph” Corona.
  • Caitlyn Stave plays Halley del Rosario.
  • Josh Ford plays Aries.
  • Kiray Celis plays Marites.
  • Arnold Reyes plays Minggoy.
  • Tanya Gomez plays Isay.
  • Sean Lucas plays Kevin.
  • Marissa Delgado plays Nova Soriano.

Guest Cast:

  • Maricar de Mesa as younger Nova
  • Ana Marin as Aurora “Auring” Vega-Corona
  • Tart Carlos as Karen
  • Christian Antolin as Sputnik
  • Kirst Viray as Delfin
  • Analyn Barro as Aera Simmons
  • Shanelle Agustin as Emily

  • Kitsi Pagaspas as Belen

  • Ryan Sandoval as Chito
  • Orlando Sol as Isko
  • Richard Arellano as Generoso
  • Rodjun Cruz as a dancer
  • Juan Rodrigo as Tiago
  • Rochelle Barrameda as Juliet
  • Anjay Anson as Sandro
  • Stanley Abuloc as Tonyo / 11-15-2-12-78-15-22-31-12

item.title: Kecksburg UFO incident
item.description:
Kecksburg UFO Incident ðŸ”—

The Kecksburg UFO incident occurred on December 9, 1965, in Kecksburg, Pennsylvania. A fireball was seen across six U.S. states and Canada. While astronomers suggested it was a meteor bolide, the event gained notoriety in popular culture and ufology. Speculation ranged from an extraterrestrial craft to debris from the Soviet space probe Kosmos 96. It’s often referred to as “Pennsylvania’s Roswell.” NASA released a statement in 2005 suggesting fragments were from a Soviet satellite, but records were reportedly lost.

Initial Reports ðŸ”—

On the evening of December 9, 1965, a large fireball was observed across multiple U.S. states and Ontario, Canada, particularly over the Detroit-Windsor area. Reports included hot metal debris in Michigan and Ohio, grass fires, and sonic booms near Pittsburgh. Residents of Kecksburg, Pennsylvania, reported blue smoke, vibrations, a “thump,” and a crash in the woods. Early reports in the Greensburg Tribune-Review mentioned the area being sealed off by U.S. Army and State Police officials. However, a subsequent search by state troopers and Air Force personnel found nothing. Authorities dismissed explanations like a plane crash or missile test, attributing it to a meteor. Astronomer Paul Annear and geophysicist George Wetherilo supported the meteor explanation, as did astronomers William P. Bidelman and Fred Hess.

Scientific Articles ðŸ”—

This section references scientific articles written about the fireball in science journals.

Sky & Telescope ðŸ”—

The February 1966 issue of Sky & Telescope reported the fireball’s sighting over the Detroit-Windsor area around 4:44 p.m. EST. The FAA received 23 reports from aircraft pilots starting at the same time. A seismograph near Detroit recorded shock waves. The article concluded the fireball’s path extended from northwest to southeast, ending near western Lake Erie.

Journal of the Royal Astronomical Society of Canada ðŸ”—

A 1967 article in the Journal of the Royal Astronomical Society of Canada (JRASC) by two astronomers used seismographic records to pinpoint the time of passage over Detroit to 4:43 p.m. Photographs taken north of Detroit were used to triangulate the object’s trajectory. The conclusion was that the fireball descended at a steep angle, moving from southwest to northeast, likely impacting the northwestern shore of Lake Erie near Windsor, Ontario.

NASA Statements ðŸ”—

In December 2005, NASA released a statement claiming experts examined metallic fragments from the area and determined they were from a Soviet satellite that re-entered the atmosphere, but records were lost in the 1980s. Leslie Kean, an investigative reporter, sued NASA under the Freedom of Information Act for the lost records. In 2007, NASA was ordered by a court to search for the records. During a hearing, NASA’s public liaison officer, Steve McConnell, testified that two boxes of relevant papers were missing. James Oberg suggested the NASA team might have been Air Force personnel posing as NASA, and that Kean’s action was a publicity stunt. John Ventre of MUFON and Owen Eichler speculated the object was a General Electric Mark 2 Re-entry Vehicle. More recent NASA comments suggest the fireball’s trajectory was inconsistent with a spacecraft re-entering from Earth orbit, more likely a meteor from the asteroid belt, and that U.S. Air Force tracking data indicated Cosmos 96 decayed earlier.

Television and Film ðŸ”—

This section details the appearances of the Kecksburg UFO incident in various television shows and films.

  • In 1990, Unsolved Mysteries aired an episode suggesting an extraterrestrial craft crashed, with locals reporting an acorn-shaped object with hieroglyphs, removed in a secret military operation. A prop from the show is displayed in Kecksburg.
  • In 2003, the Sci Fi Channel aired “The New Roswell: Kecksburg Exposed,” featuring a Kecksburg resident claiming to have seen a flat-bed truck carrying something “the size of a VW.”
  • In 2008, Nazi UFO Conspiracy suggested the incident was the recovery of a Nazi UFO called Die Glocke.
  • In 2009, UFO Hunters suggested a military conspiracy and cover-up.
  • In 2011, Ancient Aliens suggested Die Glocke was recovered at Kecksburg, prompting a government conspiracy.
  • In 2014, In Search of Aliens visited the crash site with UFO researcher Stan Gordon.
  • In 2019, Cody Knotts premiered his film Kecksburg, dramatizing the story of a reporter claiming to be a victim of a government conspiracy.
  • Andrew Patterson cited the Kecksburg incident as partial inspiration for his 2019 film The Vast of Night.
  • BBC Radio 4’s 2024 drama series, Limelight: The Skies Are Watching, uses the Kecksburg incident as its inspiration.

See Also ðŸ”—

This section lists related topics, including a list of UFO sightings and Die Glocke (conspiracy theory).

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kecksburg_UFO_incident

item.title: Roswell, New Mexico (TV series)
item.description:
Roswell, New Mexico (TV series) ðŸ”—

This entry provides an overview of the American science fiction drama television series Roswell, New Mexico, a reboot of the Roswell High book series by Melinda Metz. It highlights the show’s development, plot, cast, production details, episode information, reception, and availability on home media.

Overview ðŸ”—

This section summarizes the premise of the show. Liz Ortecho returns to her hometown of Roswell, New Mexico, and discovers that her teenage crush, Max Evans, is an alien. As they reconnect, they must protect his secret while facing threats from a greater alien presence and the politics of fear and hatred.

Cast and characters ðŸ”—

This section lists the main and recurring cast members and their characters.

Main ðŸ”—

  • Jeanine Mason as Liz Ortecho, a biomedical researcher and daughter of undocumented immigrants.
  • Nathan Dean as Max Evans, a Roswell deputy sheriff and alien.
  • Michael Vlamis as Michael Guerin, a troubled alien drifter.
  • Lily Cowles as Isobel Evans, Max’s sister and an alien.
  • Tyler Blackburn as Alex Manes, an Air Force veteran.
  • Heather Hemmens as Maria DeLuca, Liz’s best friend and a bartender.
  • Michael Trevino as Kyle Valenti, a doctor and son of the town sheriff.
  • Trevor St. John as Jesse Manes (seasons 1â€“2), Alex’s father.
  • Karan Oberoi as Noah Bracken (season 1; guest season 2), Isobel’s husband.
  • Amber Midthunder as Rosa Ortecho (seasons 2â€“4; recurring season 1), Liz’s older sister.

Recurring ðŸ”—

This section lists recurring characters, including:

  • Carlos Compean as Arturo Ortecho, Liz’s father.
  • Peter Diseth as Grant/Graham Green, an alien theorist and museum proprietor.
  • Kayla Ewell as Nora Truman, Michael’s biological mother.
  • Rosa Arredondo as Michelle Valenti, Kyle’s mother and sheriff.
  • Dylan McTee as Wyatt Long, the brother of one of Rosa’s victims.
  • Riley Voelkel as Jenna Cameron, Max’s deputy partner.
  • Sherri Saum as Mimi DeLuca, Maria’s mother.
  • Claudia Black as Ann Evans, Max and Isobel’s adoptive mother.
  • Kiowa Gordon as Flint Manes, Alex Manes’ older brother.
  • Justina Adorno as Steph, Kyle’s love interest.
  • Jason Behr as Tripp Manes, Alex Manes’ great-uncle.
  • Cassandra Jean Amell as Louise Truman, Isobel’s biological mother.
  • Gaius Charles as Roy Bronson, a farmer from 1947.
  • Jamie Clayton as Grace Powell / Charlie Cameron, Jenna Cameron’s sister.
  • Cleo Anthony as Diego, Liz’s ex-fiancÃ©.
  • Christian Antidormi as Forrest Long, Alex Manes’ love interest.
  • Tanner Novlan as Gregory Manes, Alex Manes’ older brother.
  • La’Charles Trask as Bert.
  • Steven Krueger as Heath, Liz’s colleague.
  • Sibongile Mlambo as Anatsa, an investigative journalist.
  • David DeSantos as Edgar.
  • Michael Grant Terry as Jordan Bernhardt, the son of Roswell’s mayor.
  • Gillian Vigman as Brooke Taylor, the town sheriff.
  • Quentin Plair as Dallas.
  • Andrew Lees as Clyde.
  • Zoe Cipres as Bonnie.
  • Rekha Sharma as Dr. Shivani Sen.

Production ðŸ”—

This section details the production aspects of the series.

Development ðŸ”—

The CW ordered the show to pilot in January 2018, with Julie Plec directing. Production companies involved include Amblin Television, Bender Brown Productions, CBS Television Studios, and Warner Bros. Television. The show was ordered to series on May 11, 2018. It was renewed for a second season on April 24, 2019, a third season on January 7, 2020, and a fourth season on February 3, 2021. The series was canceled after four seasons on May 12, 2022.

Casting ðŸ”—

Jeanine Mason was cast as Liz Ortecho on February 16, 2018. The rest of the main cast, including Nathan Parsons, Lily Cowles, Michael Vlamis, Tyler Blackburn, Heather Hemmens, and Michael Trevino, was cast in early March 2018. Karan Oberoi was cast as Noah Bracken on March 27, 2018. Trevor St. John was cast as Alex’s father on March 12, 2018. Amber Midthunder was promoted to the main cast for the second season in April 2019. Tanner Novlan was cast in a recurring role as Alex’s brother, Gregory, in May 2020.

Filming ðŸ”—

Filming for the pilot took place in Albuquerque and Santa Fe, New Mexico, beginning on March 14, 2018, and ending on March 30, 2018. The rest of the first-season episodes began filming on August 13, 2018, in Las Vegas, New Mexico, and Santa Fe, New Mexico. Filming for the third season began on October 15, 2020, and the fourth and final season started in August 2021 and concluded in January 2022.

Episodes ðŸ”—

This section provides an overview of the series’ episodes, including a series overview and detailed information for each season.

Series overview ðŸ”—

This section presents a table summarizing the number of episodes, first released date, and last released date for each of the four seasons.

Season 1 (2019) ðŸ”—

This section lists each episode of the first season, including the title, director, writer(s), original release date, U.S. viewers (in millions), and a brief summary of the plot.

Season 2 (2020) ðŸ”—

This section lists each episode of the second season, including the title, director, writer(s), original release date, U.S. viewers (in millions), and a brief summary of the plot.

Season 3 (2021) ðŸ”—

This section lists each episode of the third season, including the title, director, writer(s), original release date, and U.S. viewers (in millions).

Season 4 (2022) ðŸ”—

This section lists each episode of the fourth season, including the title, director, writer(s), original release date, and U.S. viewers (in millions).

Reception ðŸ”—

This section summarizes the critical reception and ratings of the series.

Critical reception ðŸ”—

The series has a 55% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, with an average rating of 6.22/10, and a critic consensus stating that the reboot hews too closely to its predecessor. Metacritic assigned the series a score of 58 out of 100, indicating “mixed or average reviews.”

Ratings ðŸ”—

This section provides viewership and ratings information for each season and episode.

Overall ðŸ”—

This section presents a table summarizing the timeslot, number of episodes, first aired date and viewership, last aired date and viewership, TV season, viewership rank, average viewers (in millions), and 18â€“49 rank for each of the four seasons.

Season 1 ðŸ”—

This section presents a table summarizing the title, air date, rating/share (18â€“49), viewers (in millions), DVR (18â€“49), DVR viewers (in millions), total (18â€“49), and total viewers (in millions) for each episode of the first season.

Season 3 ðŸ”—

This section presents a table summarizing the title, air date, rating/share (18â€“49), viewers (in millions), DVR (18â€“49), DVR viewers (in millions), total (18â€“49), and total viewers (in millions) for each episode of the third season.

Season 4 ðŸ”—

This section presents a table summarizing the title, air date, rating (18â€“49), and viewers (in millions) for each episode of the fourth season.

Home media ðŸ”—

This section notes that Warner Archive Collection released a manufacture-on-demand DVD of the first season on January 28, 2020.

Notes ðŸ”—

This section provides clarifying notes, including:

  • CBS Television Studios was credited as CBS Television Studios from 2019 to
